data.title: Allow users to enable or disable the automatic changing of indent
data.body: This is less of a serious pull request, and more a prompt for discussion. I've written a proof of concept that disables automatic changing of indent based on a setting on the preferences screen.

data.title: Add missing colon
data.body:
First pull request, yay!
Adds a colon in the advanced keymaps doc so that direct copy/paste works.

data.title: Cannot delete files from mounted volume
data.body:
Hi. I have faced a problem deleting a files located on a folder mounted through the sshfs. Atom wants to move files to trash and it is, obviously, not possible. 
Is there an option to enable permanent deleting when moving to trash is unavailable or just force to delete permanently every time.
Thanks.

data.title: styles.less no longer being applied
data.body: I recently updated from 150 to 177, and my styles.less is no longer applied. Deprecation Cop tells me that `editor` is now `atom-text-editor`, but doesn't specify this error existing in styles.less. I've changed it to reflect this and it's still not being applied.

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'isActive' of null

See these issues :
https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5402
https://github.com/atom-community/autocomplete-plus/issues/241
1. Had two tabs open (the first was my code, the second was the settings)
2. Pressed "Update All" to update different packages
3. While packages were just starting to download, went back to my first tab and tried modifying some code (namely, I just pressed the enter bar)

data.title: External config documentation
data.body:
Per advice of @thomasjo in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/5429#issuecomment-73186684, added the following to config.coffee documentation to help other users:
#### External Config Schemas

If you would like to store your schema in an external file and require it, you must require it prior to setting the `config` value in `module.exports`:

```
ConfigSchema = require('./configuration.coffee')
module.exports =
  config: ConfigSchema
```

not:

```
module.exports =
  config: require('./configuration.coffee')
```

data.title: Menu bar keyboard shortcuts conflict
data.body:
When the "Auto Hide Menu Bar" is enabled in the settings, some of the keyboard combinations to bring it up do not work, because they seem to conflict with other assignments eg Alt + f and Alt + h

To reproduce:
1. Check "Auto Hide Menu Bar" in settings
2. Have a file opened
3. Clicking Alt + f will behave like Ctrl + Right arrow, instead of opening the "File" popup from the menu bar

data.title: Highlight same string as currently selected
data.body:
In my previous text editor I could just select some text/code and would then see all other occurrences highlighted in the view. From there on I could jump to each one by a simple shortcut (it put the selection into the finder and then normal jumping between results could occur).

Would be great to have it also in Atom!

data.title: Refresh GitRepository status constantly
data.body:
Closes #5301 

/cc: @benogle

data.title: Cannot save: Uncaught ReferenceError: spawnSync is not defined
data.body:
I had this error before, realised I was on a rather old version of Atom and updated to the latest  (0.153 on Windows 7 64-bit). The update resolved the issue for a while, but now it's back again.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Start Atom
2. Open my timesheet.txt file
3. Make changes
4. Try to save (Ctrl-S or File->Save)

At this point Atom fails to save the file (blue 'unsaved' icon remains and changes are not saved to disk).

There are two errors visible in the developer tools (with full stacktraces):
![atomcannotsavetrace](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6697562/6075274/d816d3ea-add7-11e4-8b07-89cf96117d67.png)

I initially thought this may be related to the file being in a Dropbox folder, but I just tried a folder in My Documents as well and it exhibits the same behaviour.

data.title: Man pages for atom and apm
data.body:
Besides the `--help` and `-h` command line options/arguments, `atom` and `apm` should also have man pages. Moreover, Emacs and Vim have online documentation for their command line arguments and/or environment variables, too:
- http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Emacs-Invocation.html#Emacs-Invocation
- http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/starting.html#vim-arguments

data.title: Deep merge of 'object' config defaults
data.body:
I have an object config value like (taken from my config rewrite for https://github.com/mattberkowitz/autoclose-html/tree/new-config): ``` neverClose: type: 'object' properties: elements: title: 'Never Close Elements' description: 'Comma delimited list of elements to never close' type: 'array' default: ['br', 'hr', 'img', 'input', 'link', 'meta', 'area', 'base', 'col', 'command', 'embed', 'keygen', 'param', 'source', 'track', 'wbr'] makeSelfClosing: title: 'Make Never Close Elements Self-Closing' description: 'Closes elements with " />" (ie
becomes
)' type: 'boolean' default: true ``` If I change the default value for one of the properties, such that my entry in config.cson looks like: ``` "autoclose-html": neverClose: makeSelfClosing: false ``` The other property wont show up in the plugins config panel, thus not allowing the user to set a value for it. This is due to the fact that `_.defaults()` does not do deep merging This change loops over the defaultValues keys, and recursively sets to `getRawValue` for each key's path.

data.title: Add hook for other implementations of [Git]Repository.
Add "Communicating with other packages" section to docs
data.body:
I'd like to provide more guidance on service names. The approach I originally envisioned is that the services would form a dot-separated namespace so that each package could own its own top-level namespace, like `autocomplete-plus.completion-provider`. Then the `atom` namespace would be reserved for core services like `atom.repository-provider`.

It's interesting that people are gravitating toward `-` separated names instead of camel-case. I sort of wish config were that way now.

data.title: open dialog for atom config directory is misleading
data.body:
When launching atom:

```
2015-02-05 16:07:09
rbellamy@eanna i ~ % atom
++ uname
+ '[' Linux == Darwin ']'
+++ uname -s
++ expr substr Linux 1 5
+ '[' Linux == Linux ']'
+ OS=Linux
+ getopts :wtfvh-: opt
+ '[' ']'
+ '[' Linux == Mac ']'
+ '[' Linux == Linux ']'
++ readlink -f /usr/bin/atom
+ SCRIPT=/usr/bin/atom
+++ dirname /usr/bin/atom
++ readlink -f /usr/bin/..
+ USR_DIRECTORY=/usr
+ ATOM_PATH=/usr/share/atom/atom
+ ATOM_HOME=/home/rbellamy/.config/atom
+ export PYTHON=/usr/bin/python2
+ PYTHON=/usr/bin/python2
+ mkdir -p /home/rbellamy/.config/atom
+ : /tmp
+ '[' -x /usr/share/atom/atom ']'
+ '[' ']'
+ trap on_die SIGQUIT SIGTERM
+ '[' ']'
++ pwd
+ nohup /usr/share/atom/atom --executed-from=/home/rbellamy --pid=29059
2015-02-05 16:07:11
rbellamy@eanna i ~ % echo $ATOM_HOME
/home/rbellamy/.config/atom

```

And then when atom opens, it's clearly not using $ATOM_HOME, which is set to ~/.config/atom, not ~/.atom.

![selection 396x364 20150205160728-0800](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/94763/6072023/497e7fa6-ad51-11e4-8456-e1da28d15d42.png)

However, when you open the folder, and copy the full path, or open in file manager, it is pointed at the correct directory.

data.title: Introduce ProjectRoot.
data.body:
Introduce ProjectRoot.

Today, Project has three methods that return parallel arrays:

```
getPaths()
getDirectories()
getRepositories()
```

Instead, there should be one type, `ProjectRoot`, that encapsulates
all of this information. Then these three methods can be replaced
with one method:

```
getProjectRoots()
```

This commit introduces the `ProjectRoot` type and the `getProjectRoots()`
method. The other three methods are now defined in terms of `getProjectRoots()`.

Note that there are two outstanding methods on `Project` that assume a single
root that seem out of place:

```
relativize(fullPath)
contains(pathToCheck)
```

data.title: Show custom notifications for more save errors
data.body:
This moves the save error handling from `Workspace` to `Pane` so that save errors from `Pane::destroyItem` and `Pane::saveItems` are now properly handled.

Also adds a notification for when `atom.config.save` fail to write the file to disk.

Closes #5292
Closes #5350
Closes #5371
Closes #5396
Closes #5421

**System**: Mac OS X 10.10.2

data.title: Unable to update Atom on Linux using Master
data.body:
I am unable to update Atom to the latest commit on `master`.

**OS:** Ubuntu 14.04
**Atom:** master branch (83c8d904cf)

It seems to fail on the `install` task

``` console
$ sudo script/grunt install
```

When running in verbose mode:

``` console
$ sudo script/grunt install -v
...
Writing /usr/local/share/atom/version...OK
Copied /tmp/atom-build/Atom to /usr/local/share/atom.
Reading package.json...OK
Parsing package.json...OK
Warning: executable is not defined Use --force to continue.

Aborted due to warnings.
```

When building from the latest tag, there is no issue.

data.title: Fix atom engine semver in upgrading docs
data.body:
This :trollface: me on two of my pacakges, as described in [this comment](https://github.com/izuzak/atom-pdf-view/issues/45#issuecomment-72206548).

apm uses `semver.validRange` to [determine if the semver of `engines.atom` is valid](https://github.com/atom/apm/blob/94d2dd96114cbbefc52ad728f5ec870d6d3ce4c6/src/install.coffee#L508), and if it isn't -- it skips that version of the package. Here's how that behaves for the recommended semver in the guide:

```
> semver.validRange(">=0.174.0, <2.0.0")

null
```

Here's how it behaves with the change suggested in this PR:

```
> semver.validRange(">=0.174.0 <2.0.0")

'>=0.174.0 <2.0.0'
```

Also, the range works as expected when testing whether a version is in that range:

```
> semver.satisfies("0.178.0", ">=0.174.0 <2.0.0")
true
> semver.satisfies("2.178.0", ">=0.174.0 <2.0.0")
false
> semver.satisfies("0.174.0", ">=0.174.0 <2.0.0")
true
> semver.satisfies("0.173.0", ">=0.174.0 <2.0.0")
false
```

As far as I can tell, this is also how ranges are explained in [`node-semver`](https://github.com/npm/node-semver#ranges).

cc @benogle

data.title: Package config only appears after package is activated
data.body:
This issue has cropped up in a couple of places and ultimately here: https://github.com/atom/settings-view/issues/356

I believe the issue is with `/src/package.coffee` and could be solved with calling `activateConfig()` in `load()` so that the defaults are loaded with the package but it will probably need a bit more tweaking than that.
